channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: Turkish Official Says Army May Have to End Protests
item.description: The comments by the deputy prime minister, Bulent Arinc, followed days of intensifying street violence and signs of a broadening government crackdown.
item.dc:creator: By KAREEM FAHIM and SEBNEM ARSU

item.title: In Montreal, Mayor Held on Charges of Bribery
item.description: Michael Applebaum, the first English speaker to hold the post in 100 years, was arrested at his home by an anticorruption police squad.
item.dc:creator: By IAN AUSTEN
item.media:description: Michael Applebaum became the mayor of Montreal, the country’s second-largest city, in November.

item.title: A More Secular Europe, Divided by the Cross
item.description: A commemorative euro coin intended to celebrate the 1,150th anniversary of Christianity’s arrival in Slovak lands became the center of a fight with the European Commission.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW HIGGINS
item.media:description: A huge European Union flag in front of the Parliament building in Bucharest, Romania, in May. The flag, with its circle of 12 yellow stars, has a coded Christian message, inspired by iconography of the Virgin Mary wearing a crown with 12 stars.

item.title: Thousands Gather for Protests in Brazil’s Largest Cities
item.description: Agitation had begun with small protests against bus-fare increases, then evolved into a broader movement by groups and individuals irate over a range of issues including the country’s high cost of living and lavish new stadium projects.
item.dc:creator: By SIMON ROMERO
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Demonstrators in Sao Paulo, Brazil, on Monday. Many Brazilians are irate over issues like the nation's high cost of living.

item.title: Obama Addresses Youth in Belfast
item.description: Before joining Group of 8 leaders, President Obama hailed the normalcy in Belfast and the economic growth, despite Europe’s recent hard times.
item.dc:creator: By JACKIE CALMES
item.media:description: President Obama acknowledged “wounds that haven’t healed" but mostly praised Northern Ireland on Monday in Belfast.

item.title: N.S.A. Leaker Denies Giving Secrets to China
item.description: In an online question-and-answer session, Edward J. Snowden said that he had not given any classified materials to the government of China, calling such speculation “a predictable smear.”
item.dc:creator: By CHARLIE SAVAGE and SCOTT SHANE
item.media:description: A TV screen showed the news of Edward J. Snowden on a subway in Hong Kong on Sunday.

item.title: Top Senator on Panel Blocks Aid to Afghans
item.description: President Hamid Karzai of Afghanistan may still be getting his monthly cash deliveries from the C.I.A. This total amounts to $75 million in American aid.
item.dc:creator: By MATTHEW ROSENBERG

item.title: After Gunfire, Politicians in Afghanistan Trade Accusations
item.description: A warlord turned politician and a provincial governor gave differing accounts of a meeting that turned violent at the governor’s home in northern Afghanistan.
item.dc:creator: By ROD NORDLAND
item.media:description: Gen. Abdul Rashid Dostum, the Uzbek political leader and warlord, speaking in 2009.

item.title: 60 Years Later, Germany Recalls Its Anti-Soviet Revolt
item.description: Germany commemorated the 60th anniversary of an uprising by East Germans against Soviet rule, seeking a higher pedestal for the little-known revolt.
item.dc:creator: By ALISON SMALE
item.media:description: Germans cast stones at Soviet tanks in East Berlin on June 17, 1953.

item.title: True or Faked, Dirt on Chinese Fuels Blackmail
item.description: A growing number of Chinese officials have found themselves ensnared by extortion plots that leverage the public’s disgust for wayward behavior.
item.category: Central Commission for Discipline Inspection (Communist Party of China)
item.dc:creator: By DAN LEVIN and AMY QIN
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrie for The New York Times
item.media:description: A sign in Suangfeng County attacked the use of Photoshop to forge compromising images of officials for use in extortion.

item.title: Large Truck Bomb Reported to Kill 60 Syrian Troops
item.description: The bombing near the northern city of Aleppo appeared to be part of an effort by the Syrian insurgency to regain momentum after a series of defeats.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE
item.media:description: Syrian rebels mounted what appeared to be one of the deadliest strikes against government forces to date on Monday, sending six tons of explosives in a truck.

item.title: Touting Islam to Draw Votes in Indonesia
item.description: The mountain town of Bogor is on the front line of a national debate about religious freedom, amid an increase in discrimination and violent attacks against minority Christians and Islamic sects.
item.dc:creator: By JOE COCHRANE
item.media:credit: Andri Tambunan for The International Herald Tribune
item.media:description: A local Christian congregation, known as GKI Yasmin, has been closed since 2008.

item.title: The Lede: Iran’s President-Elect Confronted With Plea for Detained Opposition Leader’s Freedom
item.description: At a news conference broadcast live on Iranian state television, a man called on Iran’s president-elect, Hassan Rowhani, not to forget the detained opposition leader Mir Hussein Moussavi.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: At War Blog: How Cyberwarfare and Drones Have Revolutionized Warfare
item.description: Tim Hsia and Jared Sperli write that the next few decades will be dominated by advancements in software and hardware (cyber and robotics, including drones) just as the last decade was dominated by counterinsurgency.
item.dc:creator: By TIM HSIA and JARED SPERLI

item.title: Syria and Russia Warn West Against Aiding Rebels
item.description: Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain said Monday that he found some elements of the Syrian opposition worrying, as Russia warned against arming the rebels.
item.dc:creator: By STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: Wave of Protests Engulfs Greece
item.description: On Monday, Greece faced the most serious political crisis since Prime Minister Antonis Samaras took power exactly a year ago, and his governing coalition appeared on the verge of unraveling.
item.dc:creator: By LIZ ALDERMAN

item.title: Room for Debate: Hopes for Change in Iran
item.description: Will the election of a moderate cleric lead to real reform, or will powerful forces protect the status quo?

item.title: Czech Governing Party Moves to Form New Government
item.description: The jockeying began after Prime Minister Petr Necas resigned over a scandal involving a close aide.
item.dc:creator: By DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: President-Elect of Iran Talks of Easing Tensions With U.S.
item.description: Speaking for the first time since his election victory, Hassan Rowhani called Iran’s nonexistent ties with the United States a “wound” that must be healed.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS ERDBRINK

item.title: France Télécom Board Backs Chief Executive
item.description: The company’s board stood behind Stéphane Richard after he was placed under formal investigation last week in connection with suspected fraud in a 2008 case.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID JOLLY

item.title: 8 Arrested in Tokyo Fights Involving Anti-Korean Group
item.description: Fistfights broke out between ultranationalist Japanese shouting anti-Korean slogans and counterprotesters on the streets of Tokyo, where public violence is rare.
item.dc:creator: By MARTIN FACKLER

item.title: India Ink: Image of the Day: June 17
item.description: Heavy rains cause road damage in a town in the northern state of Uttarakhand.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: A road damaged after heavy rains near the town of Govindghat in Uttarakhand.

item.title: North Korea to Send Senior Envoy to China
item.description: The strategic talks will focus on bilateral relations and the situation on the Korean Peninsula.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: China Court Ruling Could Threaten Foreign Investments in Country
item.description: A recent Supreme People’s Court ruling has highlighted the precariousness of contracts behind major foreign investments in some big Chinese companies.
item.dc:creator: By SUE-LIN WONG
item.media:description: A Baidu conference in Beijing. Baidu is one of the companies that has created a variable interest entity.

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: Defenders of Public Spaces Take Inspiration From Turkish Protests
item.description: The Turkish protest movement began as a reaction to the impending loss of Istanbul’s Gezi Park to make way for a shopping mall. Campaigns elsewhere indicate that fears about the privatization of public space are not confined to Turkey.
item.dc:creator: By HARVEY MORRIS
item.media:description: Anti-G8 protesters at London's Canary Wharf financial district on Friday.
